body:
> If the `@Nested` test classes in `ExecutionOrderForNestedTests` are discovered in a `@Suite` using classpath scanning via `@SelectPackages`, the `@Nested` test methods get executed **before** the test methods in enclosing classes, which was not previously the case.

Again, although the particular scenario I have outlined is perhaps unusual, the behavior has in fact changed, and I think the original behavior is "more correct" in terms of "top-down" test method execution order within `@Nested` class hierarchies within a `@Suite`.

> For example, `TripleNestedWithInheritedAndLocalExtensionsTests.test()` fails as follows when run in one of those failing `@Suite` scenarios.
> 
> ```
> org.opentest4j.AssertionFailedError: 
> Expecting actual:
>   ["Foo", "Bar", "Foo", "Bar", "Baz", "Foo", "Bar", "Baz", "Qux"]
> to contain exactly (and in same order):
>   ["Foo", "Bar", "Baz", "Qux"]
> but some elements were not expected:
>   ["Foo", "Bar", "Foo", "Bar", "Baz"]
> ```

To be honest, that's also a bit strange.

It fails differently in a suite than it does when run standalone.

If you run `TripleNestedWithInheritedAndLocalExtensionsTests.test()` directly by itself, it fails as follows.

```
org.opentest4j.AssertionFailedError: 
Expecting actual:
  ["Foo", "Foo", "Bar", "Foo", "Bar", "Baz", "Foo", "Bar", "Baz", "Qux"]
to contain exactly (and in same order):
  ["Foo", "Bar", "Baz", "Qux"]
but some elements were not expected:
  ["Foo", "Foo", "Bar", "Foo", "Bar", "Baz"]
```

Note the additional leading `"Foo"` in the "actual" result in the above, which actually makes sense in terms of the structure of the test classes.

Whereas, the missing leading `"Foo"` in the suite variant seems a bit mysterious. ðŸ˜‰

issue.title: Only find non-inner classes during class path scanning

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

A change in 5.13.0 led to inner classes being discovered during class
path scanning which caused them to be added to their parent descriptors
before their sibling test methods. This made the order of execution in
classes containing nested test classes dependent on how they were
discovered.

The change in this commit avoids inner classes from being discovered
during classpath scanning so they won't be added earlier than their
sibling test methods again.

Resolves #4600.

---

I hereby agree to the terms of the [JUnit Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/002a0052926ddee57cf90580fa49bc37e5a72427/CONTRIBUTING.md#junit-contributor-license-agreement).

---

### Definition of Done

- [x] There are no TODOs left in the code
- [x] Method [preconditions](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/api/org.junit.platform.commons/org/junit/platform/commons/util/Preconditions.html) are checked and documented in the method's Javadoc
- [x] [Coding conventions](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#coding-conventions) (e.g. for logging) have been followed
- [x] Change is covered by [automated tests](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#tests) including corner cases, errors, and exception handling
- [x] Public API has [Javadoc](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#javadoc) and [`@API` annotations](https://apiguardian-team.github.io/apiguardian/docs/current/api/org/apiguardian/api/API.html)
- [ ] Change is documented in the [User Guide](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/) and [Release Notes](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/#release-notes)

issue.title: Ensure `@Nested` classes are executed after sibling test methods

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

In order to validate them, classpath scanning was changed to find them
in 5.13.0. However, that caused `@Nested` classes to be added to their
parent descriptors before their sibling test methods. This made the
order of execution in classes containing nested test classes dependent
on how they were discovered unless a `MethodOrderer` was configured in
which case `MethodOrderingVisitor` ensured test methods came before
`@Nested` test classes on the same level.

This commit changes `MethodOrderingVisitor` to also ensure this
ordering constraint in case no `MethodOrderer` is configured.

Resolves #4600.

---

I hereby agree to the terms of the [JUnit Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/002a0052926ddee57cf90580fa49bc37e5a72427/CONTRIBUTING.md#junit-contributor-license-agreement).

---

### Definition of Done

- [x] There are no TODOs left in the code
- [x] Method [preconditions](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/api/org.junit.platform.commons/org/junit/platform/commons/util/Preconditions.html) are checked and documented in the method's Javadoc
- [x] [Coding conventions](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#coding-conventions) (e.g. for logging) have been followed
- [x] Change is covered by [automated tests](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#tests) including corner cases, errors, and exception handling
- [x] Public API has [Javadoc](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#javadoc) and [`@API` annotations](https://apiguardian-team.github.io/apiguardian/docs/current/api/org/apiguardian/api/API.html)
- [x] Change is documented in the [User Guide](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/) and [Release Notes](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/#release-notes)

body:
A workaround is to configure a `MethodOrderer`, for example, as an annotation on the `Suite` class:

```java
@ConfigurationParameter(
	key = "junit.jupiter.testmethod.order.default", 
	value = "org.junit.jupiter.api.MethodOrderer$OrderAnnotation"
)
```

rename.from: `@Nested` tests are no longer executed top-down in a `@Suite` using `@SelectPackages`
rename.to: `@Nested` tests are executed in reverse order when selected via classpath scanning

rename.from: `@Nested` tests are executed in reverse order when selected via classpath scanning
rename.to: `@Nested` tests are executed in inverted order when selected via classpath scanning
